To this I would respond that most bugs are introduced as unforeseen 
consequences of modification to existing code.  There may be 
interdependencies that we weren't aware of.  Most bugs seem obvious once 
they're discovered.  What you're saying makes sense if we only ever 
knowingly change the implementation of a method, but it doesn't give me 
much confidence that I'm not inadvertently breaking functioning code when I 
make modifications.

And besides testing get methodds are generally pretty darn easy.  In 
response to the question "Why do it?" I say "Why not do it?"

At 12:46 PM 12/21/2001 -0600, you wrote:
> > -----------------------------------------
> >              Keep it simple...
> > (1 Corinthians 2:2, Galatians 2:20, 6:14)
>
>Exactly the philosophy of eXtreme Programming where JUnit probably has its 
>roots.
>Instead of predicting what the function will do in the future, it's 
>preferable to
>work
>with the present, and not have a test for it. If and when it changes to a more
>complex
>implementation, by all means, add a test.
>regards,
>Nilesh
>
>
